author: By Sean Piccoli
title: Family of Slain Barnard Student Criticizes Sentence for 14-Year-Old
description: One of three teenagers charged in the killing of Tessa Majors could be freed this year after he pleaded guilty to robbery in the case.
content: A teenager who admitted taking part in a mugging that preceded the stabbing death of a Barnard College student was sentenced on Monday to up to 18 months in a juvenile detention center, where he will undergo mental health counseling and be able to continue his education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Chute
title: Superman Returns, to Beat Up the Klan
description: A new Superman comic, written by Gene Luen Yang, and a medical memoir about a rare and debilitating disease are both featured in the latest Graphic Content column.
content: There are some good stories behind the new DC title SUPERMAN SMASHES THE KLAN (DC Graphic Novels for Young Adults, paper, $16.99). One is the story of the writer. Gene Luen Yang’s parents are immigrants to the United States from Taiwan and China and he grew up in California a comics fan. (His first comic book was a Superman title.) At Berkeley he majored in computer science, and ended up working in engineering before teaching high school for 17 years. Yang pursued comics on the side, self-publishing under the imprint Humble Comics, and eventually crafted a full-length graphic novel: 2006’s dark, edgy “American Born Chinese” — the book that would make his name. He quit his teaching job only in 2016, the same year he became one of a handful of cartoonists ever to win a MacArthur fellowship, and the same year he was appointed a National Ambassador for Young People’s Literature by the Library of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: As Meat Plants Stayed Open to Feed Americans, Exports to China Surged
description: While lobbying to keep operating during the pandemic, the U.S. industry sent a record amount of pork to a country vital to its growth.
content: Smithfield Foods was the first company to warn in April that the coronavirus pandemic was pushing the United States “perilously close to the edge in terms of our meat supply.” Tyson Foods also sounded the alarm, saying that “millions of pounds of meat will disappear” from the nation’s supply chain as plants were being forced to close because of outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Protests in Paris as France Reckons With Racism
description: The death of George Floyd in Minneapolis has sparked protests around the world, and has pushed other countries to address police brutality in their own cities.
content: The death of George Floyd in Minneapolis has sparked protests around the world, and has pushed other countries to address police brutality in their own cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Royal Ascot Continues, With Face Masks Instead of Top Hats
description: “I am sure,” Queen Elizabeth wrote in a statement, “it will remain one of Britain’s finest sporting occasions.” Plus, a minor league plays ball, and talk of the Tokyo Olympics in 2022.
content: There was no parade of royals, no throng of fashionable spectators in top hats and fascinators. But the normally glamorous Royal Ascot horse racing meeting still got underway as usual on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Conviction in the Philippines Reveals Facebook’s Dangers
description: The conviction of the journalist Maria Ressa shows that Facebook’s harms can’t be ignored.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: As Travel Resumes, Wineries, Cooking Schools and Others Get Creative
description: Distilleries, cooking schools, wineries and food halls from California to South Minneapolis are adjusting to social distancing and hygiene in a new era of travel.
content: There’s a constant stream of news around reopenings, from workplaces and beaches to hair salons and entire countries. But few plans are as complex as those surrounding the food-and-beverage industry, one of the harder hit sectors in these months of Covid-19-driven shutdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Exploits Conspiracy Mill Americans Built
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 16, 2020.
content: “The Kremlin doesn’t need to make fake news anymore. It’s all American-made.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda Seymour
title: How Did Bram Stoker Dream Up ‘Dracula’? A Novel Offers Hints
description: Joseph O’Connor’s “Shadowplay” explores Stoker’s time as a London theater worker and his fiery relationship with the actor-manager Henry Irving.
content: SHADOWPLAYBy Joseph O’Connor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: New Yorkers Are Backsliding on Social Distancing
description: Many  are  disregarding rules, prompting state officials to threaten to reinstate restrictions to guard against another wave of coronavirus infections.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Waits for Trump to Finish Descending the Ramp
description: “Whoa, is that President Trump or The Flash? Slow down, Usain Bolt,” Seth Meyers joked of the president’s defensive tweet about his descent from a stage at West Point.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: After Federal Crackdown on Protests, House Will Vote on Making D.C. a State
description: Democratic leaders announced a vote on June 26 on granting statehood to the District of Columbia, the first such action in more than 25 years.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats announced on Tuesday that the House would vote this month on statehood for the District of Columbia, capitalizing on anger over the Trump administration’s handling of racial justice protests in the nation’s capital to set the first vote on the issue in more than a quarter-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Kaiser
title: What Makes Monday’s Gay Rights Ruling So Historic
description: Inspired by the civil rights movement, it was decades in the making.
content: More quickly and more permanently than any other American institution, the United States Supreme Court has the capacity to set the tone for the treatment of any minority group, often for decades to come. It was a string of Supreme Court cases that transformed the status of black Americans, for example, most famously in Brown v. Board of Education in 1954.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Kristin Linklater, Who Made Actors Their Vocal Best, Dies at 84
description: Her methods went beyond mere diction and emphasized getting the whole body (and inner self) involved in speaking the words.
content: Kristin Linklater, a vocal coach renowned for helping actors free their inner voices, died on June 5 at her home in the Orkney Islands of Scotland. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Bold and the Beautiful’ to Resume Production With On-Set Covid Rules
description: The CBS daytime soap, set and filmed in Los Angeles, will begin shooting on Wednesday for the first time since March 17.
content: The Forresters will be back scheming and sashaying on set on Wednesday when CBS’s soap opera “The Bold and the Beautiful” becomes what is believed to be the first scripted U.S. broadcast series to return to production amid the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Confederate Symbols Are Coming Down. Should Dolly Parton Go Up Instead?
description: A petition is calling for Tennessee to replace statues and memorials of Confederate generals with the trailblazing performer.
content: As calls grow to rid the nation of Confederate memorials, another movement is rising to replace them with the likeness of an icon many feel represents the opposite of hatred and oppression: Dolly Parton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cliff Albright and LaTosha Brown
title: Georgia Set Up a Polling Place in a Nursing Home
description: And other horror stories from a voting meltdown.
content: ATLANTA — On what should have been a signal day for democracy last week, when voters cast ballots in the statewide primary elections, the signs of a debacle were visible early: malfunctioning voting equipment, a bungled response to the pandemic, too few polling stations and the looming specter of police violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Epps
title: Abolishing Qualified Immunity Is Unlikely to Alter Police Behavior
description: A host of reasons raise questions about the effectiveness of this reform.
content: The national movement galvanized by the killing of George Floyd has created the possibility of transformational change to policing. One reform that has generated broad discussion is eliminating “qualified immunity,” the court-created doctrine that makes it difficult for people whose civil rights are violated by police officers to obtain money damages in lawsuits. There are good arguments for getting rid of this immunity, or at least seriously restricting it. But abolishing it is unlikely to change police behavior all that much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Museler
title: Harry Anderson, ‘ M.V.P. of American Sailing,’ Is Dead at 98
description: A scion of a patrician family familiar to yacht clubs, he devoted his life to racing and its rules, with a hand in the America’s Cup, the Olympics and training the young.
content: Harry Anderson, with ancestral ties to American wealth and power going back to Aaron Burr, learned to sail as a boy at Seawanhaka, a venerable yacht club on Long Island’s North Shore, its gabled clubhouse rising from a green bluff on Centre Island overlooking Oyster Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘The Pollinators’ Review: Fight of the Honeybee
description: Colorful close-ups of thriving bees and interviews with experts show the trials that the bees and the food supply face in the United States.
content: The trials of the humble honeybee are magnified to epic proportions in the meticulous, magnificent documentary “The Pollinators.” Combining extensive interviews with purposeful nature photography, the film presents a thoroughly researched look at the causes and effects of the rapidly declining bee population, essential for the food supply in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Seahorse: The Dad Who Gave Birth’ Review: When He’s Expecting
description: In this absorbing documentary, a transgender man experiences pregnancy.
content: Shortly before turning 30, Freddy McConnell, a freelance journalist who has worked at The Guardian, made the decision to bear a child. In “Seahorse: The Dad Who Gave Birth,” McConnell, who is transgender, explains that he saw the decision to carry the pregnancy himself as “the pragmatic thing to do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Michael Crowley
title: Republicans Signal Narrow Policing Overhaul as Trump Signs Limited Order
description: Republicans denounced a sweeping Democratic law enforcement overhaul as an overreach and President Trump signed an order that omitted mention of racism or discrimination in policing.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans signaled on Tuesday that they were coalescing around a narrow set of law enforcement reforms as President Trump signed an executive order to encourage — but not mandate — that police departments alter their behavior, setting up an election-year clash with Democrats who are pushing for sweeping changes to address systemic racism in policing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott James
title: Coronavirus Economy Especially Harsh for Transgender People
description: As the pandemic ravages the country, there are concerns that an already marginalized group will be further left behind.
content: This article is part of our latest Pride special report, featuring L.G.B.T.Q. voices on the challenges and possibilities of these troubled times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: ‘If I Was Martha, What Would I Do?’ For One, Stay Upright
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has reimagined a lost 1937 solo, inspired by the Spanish Civil War, for the digital world.
content: The choreographer Martha Graham “had been in a valley of despair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: How Should I Think About Race When Considering a Sperm Donor?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on thinking about race when choosing a sperm donor and whether it’s OK to call the cops on your neighbors.
content: I am an American woman, of Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry, and I strive to live my life as an active agent against racism and white supremacy. I am beginning to consider having children and am open to bearing a child as a single mother. It is possible to sort through sperm donors by race, eye color, education level and so on. If I choose a donor of color, am I condemning my child to be born into a system designed not to serve them? Or can I use my white privilege to help them fight that system? Would my future child of color feel separated from their heritage with me as their mother? If I choose a white donor, am I succumbing to racist ideas of what traits are “desirable,” or taking the “easy road” in knowing my child will look more like me? What do you think? Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Williams, Libby Seline and Rebecca Griesbach
title: Coronavirus Cases Rise Sharply in Prisons Even as They Plateau Nationwide
description: Prison officials have been reluctant to do widespread virus testing even as infection rates are escalating.
content: Cases of the coronavirus in prisons and jails across the United States have soared in recent weeks, even as the overall daily infection rate in the nation has remained relatively flat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: New York’s New Bar Stool: The Sidewalk
description: Reopening may be a long way off, but bar regulars have reassembled outdoors, and owners are trying to balance business and safety.
content: Tony Auliano and his wife, Melinda Lantz, stood, drinks in hand, outside the Factory 380, an Andy Warhol-themed bar on Third Avenue in Manhattan, on a recent Friday night. Mr. Auliano, 63, would have rather have been inside the bar, which, like many in New York City these days, is selling drinks to go. But he was happy for any social interaction he could get.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​North Korea’s Wrecking of Liaison Office a ‘Death Knell’ for Ties With the South
description: The destruction of the office was a message aimed at President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who had brokered failed talks between the North and the Trump administration. But it was also a message for Washington.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean warning aimed at South Korea has steadily been escalating in intensity for more than a year: Your matchmaking diplomacy between our leader and President Trump is failing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jericho Brown, Carmen Maria Machado and Thomas Page McBee
title: What Does Pride Mean Now?
description: Fifty years after the first Pride March, the authors Jericho Brown, Carmen Maria Machado and Thomas Page McBee reflect on a complicated moment for the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: This article is part of our latest Pride special report, featuring L.G.B.T.Q. voices on the challenges and possibilities of these troubled times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Arizona Wildfires Force Hundreds to Evacuate as Coronavirus Cases Surge
description: The Bush Fire, northeast of Phoenix, has burned 64,000 acres as firefighters struggle against high winds and dry summer heat.
content: Wildfires across Arizona have forced hundreds to evacuate their homes, fleeing blazes — including one that has already consumed over 100 square miles — as the state grapples with a spike in confirmed coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: A Top Chicago Restaurant Messaged Its Virtue. Then Workers Spoke Up.
description: Since Fat Rice proclaimed its support for justice, former employees have come forward with complaints that its chef created a hostile work environment.
content: Two weeks ago, Abe Conlon and Adrienne Lo decided to declare their solidarity with the fight for racial justice. They did so with two posts on the Instagram account of Fat Rice, their award-winning restaurant in Chicago: one a plain black square, the other a photo of the words “Stand for change” spray-painted inside a heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Tulsa Officials Plead for Trump to Cancel Rally as Virus Spikes in Oklahoma
description: President Trump will hold his first campaign rally in months on Saturday in Oklahoma, where infections are rising, and officials there are pleading with him to cancel or hold it outdoors.
content: WASHINGTON — Officials in Tulsa, Okla., are warning that President Trump’s planned campaign rally on Saturday — his first in over three months — is likely to worsen an already troubling spike in coronavirus infections and could become a disastrous “super spreader.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niccoló F. Meriggi and Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak
title: This Country Fought Ebola. It May Beat Another Disease.
description: How to combat Covid-19 in a developing economy.
content: The coronavirus has struck the world’s most powerful economies first, leading countries in Europe, North America and East Asia to carry out an array of strategies to help control its spread. But as the virus picks up speed across the global south, those policies may not be applicable there. Low- and middle-income countries like Bangladesh, Pakistan, Indonesia and Nigeria should not blindly follow strategies that are sensible for richer nations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Ask Returning Workers to Sign a Waiver
description: A lawyer says employees often have no idea how safe the workplace will be. Also: Representative Jan Schakowsky, on Covid-19 tests for nursing home workers; Brazil’s response to the pandemic.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A Mad Scramble to Stock Millions of Malaria Pills, Likely for Nothing
description: Before the F.D.A. withdrew its waiver to stockpile the drugs as coronavirus treatments, the Trump administration had embarked on a headlong effort to import tens of millions of doses.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration’s abrupt decision this week to revoke an emergency waiver for two malaria drugs promoted by President Trump as potential “game changers” against the coronavirus has left 66 million doses stranded in the federal stockpile — and officials do not yet know what they will do with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Common Drug Reduces Coronavirus Deaths, Scientists Report
description: A steroid, dexamethasone, is the first drug shown to help save severely ill coronavirus patients, according to scientists in Britain.
content: LONDON — In an unexpected sign of hope amid the expanding pandemic, scientists at the University of Oxford said on Tuesday that an inexpensive and commonly available drug reduced deaths in patients with severe Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Why People Are Still Avoiding the Doctor (It’s Not the Virus)
description: At first, people delayed medical care for fear of catching Covid. But as the pandemic caused staggering unemployment, medical care has become unaffordable for many.
content: At first, Kristina Hartman put off getting medical care out of concern about the coronavirus. But then she lost her job as an administrator at a truck manufacturer in McKinney, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: For China and India, a Border Dispute That Never Ended
description: The countries went to war over the boundary in the Himalayas in 1962. Despite an uneasy truce and a “Line of Actual Control,” clashes still erupt.
content: Twenty Indian soldiers were killed by Chinese troops late Monday in a clash along the disputed India-China border, the first such episode in decades, military experts said. The violence is a continuation of a decades-old dispute between the two nuclear powers over the precise location of their Himalayan border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
title: PG&E Pleads Guilty to 84 Counts of Manslaughter in Camp Fire Case
description: The California utility’s transmission line started the 2018 fire that killed dozens and destroyed the town of Paradise.
content: In a nearly empty courtroom on Tuesday, the chief executive of Pacific Gas & Electric stood in front of a judge and said the same three words more than 80 times: “Guilty, your honor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Oklahoma State’s Gundy Apologizes for Wearing Shirt of Right-Wing Channel
description: Gundy’s players threatened a boycott when he wore a shirt promoting One America News Network.
content: Mike Gundy, the winningest football coach in Oklahoma State’s history, apologized on Tuesday after he stirred outrage by wearing a T-shirt with the logo of a right-wing cable channel that aired commentary calling the Black Lives Matter movement “a farce.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Descend by Rope
description: Alex Eaton-Salners squares things away.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Alex Eaton-Salners, he was trying to send us a message in Morse code. In this puzzle, nothing is definite unless you count the shaded squares.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An L.G.B.T. Landmark
description: In an unexpected ruling, the Supreme Court said that the Civil Rights Act protects workers if they’re fired “merely for being gay or transgender.”
content: The Fed’s move to buy individual corporate bonds on the open market, instead of just newly issued debt or E.T.F.s, is fueling a rally today. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Alan Rappeport
title: Congress Steps Up Pressure as Trump Administration Evades Bailout Oversight
description: As independent watchdogs sound an oversight alarm, House Democrats demand to know who got $500 billion in small-business loans.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats opened an investigation on Monday into the distribution of more than $500 billion in small-business loans under a pandemic relief program, escalating a clash with the Trump administration as it resists oversight of trillions of dollars in coronavirus assistance funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Tracking the Next Purge
description: Democrats have a new tool to identify voters who have been removed from the rolls.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Reichl, Samantha Irby, Alexander Chee, Adam Platt, Sloane Crosley, Bill Buford and Carmen Maria Machado
title: Our Lives Happen in Restaurants
description: Renowned writers remember some of their funniest, best, strangest and most memorable meals out.
content: Renowned writers remember some of their funniest, best, strangest and most memorable meals out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Music From a Distance? Eivind Opsvik Has Been Making It for Years
description: The Norwegian bassist’s group, Overseas, is releasing a live album featuring a decade’s worth of his immersive compositions.
content: The bassist Eivind Opsvik remembers the first time he heard the term “overseas,” which would become the name of his long-running ensemble. He had recently moved to New York from his native Norway, to pursue a master’s degree at the Manhattan School of Music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What Should Be Done About the Police?
description: From abolition to reinforcement, there are a lot of different ways to think through the problem.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. A question I never thought I’d ask: Should we abolish the police?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: The Minnesota Freedom Fund Has $30 Million and an Identity Crisis
description: The sole employee of the bail fund is in arbitration with the board, after anonymous accusations were lodged about her identity.
content: In the weeks following the killing of George Floyd, tens of millions of dollars have flowed into small nonprofit organizations in Minnesota. Now many donors would like to know how those funds will be distributed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Falsely Claims Obama ‘Never Even Tried’ to Address Police Misconduct
description: The president has reversed or limited efforts at reform that his predecessor enacted.
content: As President Trump signed an executive order on Tuesday encouraging changes to policing, he falsely accused his predecessor, President Barack Obama, of choosing not to tackle the issue. Here’s a fact-check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Three Futures for the Police
description: A better status quo, a possible transformation or a potential tragedy.
content: American policing is going to emerge changed from this June of protest. The question is whether it will be altered for the better. So let’s consider three possible scenarios for change — one building on the current system, another more ambitious but also riskier, and a third to be avoided at all costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Three Futures for the Police
description: A better status quo, a possible transformation or a potential tragedy.
content: American policing is going to emerge changed from this June of protest. The question is whether it will be altered for the better. So let’s consider three possible scenarios for change — one building on the current system, another more ambitious but also riskier, and a third to be avoided at all costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dillon Hayes
title: A Black Cowboy Confronts the Whitewashed History of the West
description: Larry Callies comes from a long line of black Americans living and working on the frontier.
content: Cowboys are among the most iconic figures of the American West. They’re mythologized as strong, independent people who live and die by their own terms on the frontier. And in movies, the people who play them are mostly white. But as with many elements of Americana, the idea of who cowboys are is actually whitewashed — scholars estimate that in the pioneer era, one in four cowboys were black. The historian Quintard Taylor writes about how before then, enslaved people “were part of the expansion of the livestock industry into colonial South Carolina, passing their herding skills down through the generations and steadily across the Gulf Coast states to Texas.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Why the Supreme Court Ruling on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights Is Such a Big Deal
description: Only some queer people get married, but almost all of them work.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: What Has Lockdown Meant for L.G.B.T.Q. Artists and Writers?
description: We asked 8 to tell us about the work they are doing in the pandemic and to talk about what lies ahead.
content: This article is part of our latest Pride special report, featuring L.G.B.T.Q. voices on the challenges and possibilities of these troubled times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Should Any Parents Be Instagramming Their Kids?
description: Sure, those of us who do may not all be Myka Stauffers. But we’re all selling some kind of story about ourselves, and using our children to do so.
content: Once upon a time, there was a scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nebraska Democrat Urged to Quit Senate Race Over Sexual Texts to Aide
description: Chris Janicek, the party’s nominee, faced calls from state Democrats to end his campaign after making sexually explicit comments about a campaign staff member in a group text that included her.
content: The Nebraska Democratic Party has withdrawn its support for its Senate candidate, Chris Janicek, after he made sexually explicit comments about one of his campaign staff members in a group text that included her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What Should Be Done About the Police?
description: From abolition to reinforcement, there are a lot of different ways to think through the problem.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. A question I never thought I’d ask: Should we abolish the police?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Tracking the Next Purge
description: Democrats have a new tool to identify voters who have been removed from the rolls.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: The Minnesota Freedom Fund Has $30 Million and an Identity Crisis
description: The sole employee of the bail fund is in arbitration with the board, after anonymous accusations were lodged about her identity.
content: In the weeks following the killing of George Floyd, tens of millions of dollars have flowed into small nonprofit organizations in Minnesota. Now many donors would like to know how those funds will be distributed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz and Charlie Savage
title: Prosecutor in Roger Stone Case Will Testify About Barr’s Intervention
description: The prosecutor is one of two Justice Department officials coming forward whom Democrats are calling whistle-blowers.
content: WASHINGTON — A career Justice Department prosecutor who quit the case against President Trump’s friend Roger J. Stone Jr. after political appointees intervened to seek a more lenient sentence has agreed to testify under subpoena next week before the House Judiciary Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘My Father the Spy’ Review: To Embrace a Parent or Denounce Him?
description: In this documentary, a journalist and translator relives the disorientation of defecting.
content: The documentary “My Father the Spy,” directed by Jaak Kilmi and Gints Grube, applies various meta flourishes to a story of multiple identities and geographic dislocation. The film begins with the translator and journalist Ieva Lesinska-Geibere, born in 1958 in then-Soviet Latvia, assessing her relationship with her father, Imants Lesinskis, described at the outset as a K.G.B. spy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: A Dance Theater of Harlem Classic With a Shot of Rhythm and Blues
description: What’s online: Robert Garland’s “Return,” Justin Peck in Miami, Wayne McGregor in London and a class from the L.A. Dance Project.
content: Dance Theater of Harlem emerged from tragedy and uprisings; the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., in 1968, was the catalyst for Arthur Mitchell, the first African-American principal dancer at New York City Ballet, to found (with his teacher, Karel Shook) a ballet school and a company that would offer dancers of color the chance to show that mastering classical dance had nothing to do with race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Locker Rooms Are Petri Dishes. Can the N.F.L. Clean Up Before Training Camp?
description: The lack of virus protocols as July’s camps approach has left many in football unsure about safety in a sport that requires contact on nearly every play and cramped quarters inside team facilities.
content: In this most unusual off-season roiled by the coronavirus pandemic, the N.F.L. has adapted by conducting business (mostly) as usual. Free agency, the college draft, rookie camp and voluntary workouts were all held on time, albeit remotely instead of in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: How a March for Black Trans Lives Became a Huge Event
description: “The violence that’s affecting black trans women and black trans folks is finally getting the attention that it deserves,” an organizer of the Brooklyn march said.
content: West Dakota, a drag queen in Brooklyn, was checking in on a fellow drag queen and mentor when they began discussing what they said was a painful reality about the George Floyd protests: Black transgender people are disproportionately the victims of police violence, but attending demonstrations against police brutality can often put them in further danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Why Protest Movements Are ‘Civil’ Only in Retrospect
description: Once history has endorsed a social movement, people tend to simplify it and downplay the opposition it faced. But while movements are happening, historians say, they are always messy.
content: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of the public imagination was a unifying figure who bridged America’s bitter racial divide and peacefully liberated the South from Jim Crow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: The A.P. Apologizes for ‘Thought for Today’ From Jefferson Davis
description: The wire service, which serves more than 2,000 newspapers, published a quotation from the leader of the Confederacy on his birth date. It ran in dozens of papers.
content: As part of a daily feature called Today in History, The Associated Press supplied newspapers across the country with a quotation from Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederate States of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Cuomo Announces Support of U.S. Open in New York
description: The backing of state officials for the tournament has been a key part of restarting the men’s and women’s tours.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Tuesday that the United States Open would be held as originally scheduled but without spectators at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens, approving a plan by the United States Tennis Association to salvage the Grand Slam tournament, one of the biggest sporting events in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: ‘We Are Part of the Problem’
description: State supreme court judges are starting to grapple publicly with the racial injustices in the criminal justice systems they oversee.
content: If after reading the 10th (or 50th) pledge of corporate solidarity with the anti-police-brutality protests your eyes are hurting from rolling so much, you’re not alone. Nike? Check. Netflix? Check. Peloton? Check. The revolution has been focus-grouped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: She Spent 16 Years as Morgan Stanley’s Diversity Chief. Now She’s Suing.
description: Marilyn Booker says she was fired in December after she tried to persuade executives to eliminate barriers to success for black financial advisers.
content: During Marilyn Booker’s 26-year career at Morgan Stanley, including 16 years as the bank’s global head of diversity, she often felt that too few of its employees were black. She was still trying to rectify the situation, right up until the morning in December when she was fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Dining in the Street? As Restaurants Reopen, Seating Moves Outdoors
description: Cities are accelerating applications and waiving fees to allow alfresco dining, but the moves are disrupting neighborhoods and cutting much-needed tax revenue.
content: As restaurants around the country look to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic, outdoor seating is becoming a survival option, and local governments are helping by cutting red tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $4.25 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: What Has Lockdown Meant for L.G.B.T.Q. Artists and Writers?
description: We asked 8 to tell us about the work they are doing in the pandemic and to talk about what lies ahead.
content: This article is part of our latest Pride special report, featuring L.G.B.T.Q. voices on the challenges and possibilities of these troubled times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz and Charlie Savage
title: Prosecutor in Roger Stone Case Will Testify About Barr’s Intervention
description: The prosecutor is one of two Justice Department officials coming forward whom Democrats are calling whistle-blowers.
content: WASHINGTON — A career Justice Department prosecutor who quit the case against President Trump’s friend Roger J. Stone Jr. after political appointees intervened to seek a more lenient sentence has agreed to testify under subpoena next week before the House Judiciary Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Over 2,000 Black People Were Lynched From 1865 to 1877, Study Finds
description: The Equal Justice Initiative has documented a rate of killing in the period following the Civil War that was far higher than the decades that followed.
content: In the fall of 1870, Guilford Coleman, a black man, was abducted from his home in Alabama, beaten to death and thrown into a well for having voted at a political convention to nominate a Republican governor. The message was received, according to local newspaper accounts: Those in favor of Reconstruction dared “not canvass the district, lest they lose their lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Kurzweil and Josh Wyner
title: Rich Kids Are Eating Up the Financial Aid Pot
description: A large share of strapped school budgets is going to “merit aid” for wealthy kids, as part of a bidding war to enroll high-income students.
content: In recent decades, many institutions of higher education have increasingly been awarding money to students who do not need that aid to afford college. More than half of the 339 public universities sampled in a paper published by New America at least doubled the amount they spent on so-called merit aid from 2001 to 2017; more than 25 percent quadrupled the amount. About two out of every five dollars these schools provided in institutional aid went to students the government deemed able to afford college without need-based aid. The schools do it because well-to-do families, overall, bring the institutions more tuition dollars than their lower income peers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Is Trump Trying to Spread Covid-19?
description: Does he start each day wondering what expert advice to ignore next?
content: When the full record of the coronavirus in America is written, historians may argue that President Trump’s biggest mistake was not what he failed to do in early 2020, when the right strategy for combating the virus was widely debated, unproven and hard. No, they will point to what Trump failed to do in June 2020, when the right strategy was clear, proven and relatively easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Should Any Parents Be Instagramming Their Kids?
description: Sure, those of us who do may not all be Myka Stauffers. But we’re all selling some kind of story about ourselves, and using our children to do so.
content: Once upon a time, there was a scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nebraska Democrat Urged to Quit Senate Race Over Sexual Texts to Aide
description: Chris Janicek, the party’s nominee, faced calls from state Democrats to end his campaign after making sexually explicit comments about a campaign staff member in a group text that included her.
content: The Nebraska Democratic Party has withdrawn its support for its Senate candidate, Chris Janicek, after he made sexually explicit comments about one of his campaign staff members in a group text that included her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Surprising Supreme Court Ruling on L.G.B.T. Rights
description: Readers celebrate the decision and discuss how some conservatives like Justice Neil Gorsuch and Barry Goldwater have steered their own course.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Air Force Sergeant With Ties to Extremist Group Charged in Federal Officer’s Death
description: The sergeant had expressed his allegiance to the so-called boogaloo movement, an extremist ideology that seeks to overthrow the U.S. government.
content: An Air Force sergeant linked to an anti-government movement was charged with murder and attempted murder on Tuesday in the shooting death of a federal security officer outside a courthouse in Oakland, Calif., last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: George Floyd Protests Stir a Difficult Debate on Race in France
description: France has long sought social justice through a commitment to universal ideals. But a younger generation is demanding recognition of racism — and remedies for it.
content: BOBIGNY, France — Luc Pechangou had never joined a protest before, not even when his own neighborhood just outside Paris was convulsed with anger over the violent arrest of a young black man from the area in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 16, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 16, 2020.
content: An article on Monday about efforts to undermine climate science research by federal employees who are wary of the scrutiny of senior officials misstated the timing of the resignation Marcy Rockman, a former climate change adaptation coordinator for the Park Service. Ms. Rockman resigned in November 2018, not last November.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Just before dawn, October 12th, 1905

title: Fighting the Coronavirus With Innovative Tech
description: Some of these devices have been around for years but are now being mustered to help keep us safe.
content: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country are coping with the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court Hands Down a Surprise
description: Conservative justices provide a historic L.G.B.T.Q. rights ruling: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: A historic court ruling, and a halting reopening. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet.

title: Budget-Friendly Projects for Social-Distancing Weekends
description: You’re probably not going to be hanging out with friends. Why not do a little work on your home?
content: With so much time spent at home, many of us are paying more attention to our surroundings — and discovering that we don’t like what we see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Through Their Breakups, They Were Always Friends
description: Sharene Wood and Guy Wood, who together run the 5001 Flavors apparel brand, each learned how to be “a we, not an I.”
content: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

author: By David Leonhardt
title: ‘Because of Sex …’
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The Supreme Court currently has a reliable five-member conservative majority on many issues — like business regulation, campaign finance, voting rights and the death penalty. On several of these issues, the court has issued sweeping decisions that throw out earlier precedents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Heather Murphy
title: Golden State Killer Suspect Expected to Plead Guilty and Avoid Death Penalty
description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. is expected to accept a life sentence later this month for a series of murders and rapes in the 1970s and ’80s, one victim and close relatives of two other victims said.
content: The man accused of committing a series of murders and rapes in California during the 1970s and ’80s — crimes that spawned widespread fear and the sobriquet “Golden State Killer” — is expected to accept a plea deal that would allow him to avoid the death penalty, one victim and close relatives of two other victims said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. is expected to accept a life sentence later this month for a series of murders and rapes in the 1970s and ’80s, one victim and close relatives of two other victims said.
content: The man accused of committing a series of murders and rapes in California during the 1970s and ’80s — crimes that spawned widespread fear and the sobriquet “Golden State Killer” — is expected to accept a plea deal that would allow him to avoid the death penalty, one victim and close relatives of two other victims said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
title: Cup Foods, a Minneapolis Corner Store Forever Tied to the Death of George Floyd
description: The corner market, the site of demonstrations and memorials, reopened on Monday. It has been a fixture in the neighborhood for more than three decades.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Scorn for the brown brick corner store keeps pouring in: “They call the cops on black people,” one person says in an online business review. “Racially profiled a man.” “Disgusting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Marie Tae McDermott
title: California’s Reckoning With Racism Continues

description: Sharene Wood and Guy Wood, who together run the 5001 Flavors apparel brand, each learned how to be “a we, not an I.”

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Bookstores Are Struggling. Is a New E-Commerce Site the Answer?
description: The rapid rise of Bookshop.org during the shutdown has been hailed as a boon for independent stores. But some booksellers worry it could become another competitor for online business.
content: In January, when Andy Hunter, the publisher of a small press, started an online bookstore that he pitched as the indie alternative to Amazon, many in the book business had their doubts. Earlier efforts to create a portal for independent booksellers had done little to chip away at Amazon’s market share, and even retailers like Barnes & Noble have struggled to compete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: How to Find a Meditation App for You
description: If you want to steal a few minutes of Zen and achieve something like contentment in the face of chaos and uncertainty, you might be tempted to download a meditation app.
content: If you want to steal a few minutes of Zen and achieve something like contentment in the face of chaos and uncertainty, you might be tempted to download a meditation app.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Tipsy, Celebratory State of Bliss’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I have one brother, Alex — a tall, broad black man who is a train operator for New York City’s M.T.A. The world is finally realizing that he’s “essential.” While Alex’s uniform may protect him from extrajudicial profiling, it also endangers him, requiring him to be exposed to the coronavirus. He’s always had to be tough, but since living with his girlfriend, he’s changed. Alex now tells my parents and me that he loves us. Out loud. I remember this change in myself when I first fell in love. Alex and I are 3,000 miles apart, but we’ve never been closer. — Kimberly Reyes
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Maurice Smith and Brooke Jarvis
title: The Return of the Platypuses
description: Rescued from Australia’s fires, a small fleet of wild platypuses is launched back into their wetland home and into an uncertain future.
content: The platypus, liberated from the pillowcase in which it had been traveling, headed straight for water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Let It Fall’ and ‘One Day at a Time’
description: A documentary on the 1992 Los Angeles riots airs on ABC, and Pop TV debuts an animated “One Day at a Time” special.
content: LET IT FALL: LOS ANGELES 1982-1992 (2017) 8 p.m. on ABC; stream on Netflix. This documentary by the director John Ridley (“American Crime”) was released on the 25th anniversary of the 1992 Los Angeles riots. ABC is resurfacing it — with a new introduction by John Legend — as police brutality and institutional racism consume the nation following the death of George Floyd. The movie traces the decade leading up to the riots, a response to a verdict that acquitted four police officers of assault for the beating of Rodney King. Ridley argues that King’s case was the straw that broke the camel’s back in a city rife with political and racial tensions. He backs his claim with nuance, interviewing retired police officials, witnesses and victims and perpetrators of violence. In her review for The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis named the movie a Critic’s Pick, calling it “wrenchingly humane.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike
title: Coronavirus, India, Platypuses: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Yisroel Friedman, Yeshiva Teacher and Scholar, Dies at 83
description: As pious as he was learned, Rabbi Friedman taught at a Brooklyn yeshiva for Orthodox Jews of the Chabad-Lubavitch sect. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Scientists in Britain say they have identified the first drug shown to reduce Covid deaths.
content: Six months into the outbreak, we have what might be the best news yet on a treatment: Scientists in Britain say they have identified the first drug shown to reduce coronavirus-related deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Most Coronavirus Tests Cost About $100. Why Did One Cost $2,315?
description: U.S. health care prices are unregulated, opaque and unpredictable. When Congress required insurers to cover Covid-19 testing, a few providers decided to take advantage.
content: In a one-story brick building in suburban Dallas, between a dentist office and a family medicine clinic, is a medical laboratory that has run some of the most expensive coronavirus tests in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Flushing the Toilet May Fling Coronavirus Aerosols All Over
description: A new study shows how turbulence from a toilet bowl can create a large plume that is potentially infectious to a bathroom’s next visitor.
content: Here’s one more behavior to be hyper-aware of in order to prevent coronavirus transmission: what you do after you use the toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Edén Pastora, ‘Commander Zero’ in Nicaragua, Dies at 83
description: A hero of the 1979 Sandinista revolution, he later turned on his comrades in arms, mounting an international campaign of political pressure and later guerrilla attacks inside the country.
content: Edén Pastora, a hero of the 1979 Sandinista revolution in Nicaragua who was known by his nom de guerre, Commander Zero — and who later turned against his victorious comrades in arms in a long counterrevolutionary war of words and guerrilla attacks that failed to budge the socialist regime in Managua — died early Tuesday in a military hospital in that city, the capital of Nicaragua. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Zachary Quinto’s Weekend: Watching ‘Magnolia’ and Letting the Dogs Out
description: The actor has spent quarantine time holed up with friends, chasing his two dogs and finding new resonances in old favorite films.
content: On the night of March 11, as the coronavirus clamped down on cultural life, the actor Zachary Quinto was in the audience at a Broadway theater, watching the recent revival of “West Side Story.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: A Playful Masterpiece That Expanded the Novel’s Possibilities
description: Two new translations of “The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas,” by Machado de Assis, is a new opportunity to enshrine the singular talent and mischief of this writer.
content: Is it possible that the most modern, most startlingly avant-garde novel to appear this year was originally published in 1881?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Thomas Freeman, Renowned Debate Coach in Texas, Dies at 100
description: His Texan Southern University team rose to national prominence, and Martin Luther King Jr., Barbara Jordan and Denzel Washington all learned from him.
content: When Thomas F. Freeman had to speak in public as a youth, he would burst into tears. Gripped by stage fright, he sobbed between words, barely able to complete a sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Demonstrations Force America to Reckon With Contentious Past
description: Protests have expanded to include demands for a more honest accounting of American history. An Air Force sergeant linked to an anti-government movement was charged with murder.

title: Most Coronavirus Tests Cost About $100. Why Did One Cost $2,315?

author: By Catie Edmondson and Nicholas Fandos
title: Tim Scott, Once Quiet on Matters of Race, Embraces Key Role on Police Reform
description: The sole black Republican senator cited his personal experiences with racism as a vital perspective to his party’s approach to a law enforcement overhaul.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Tim Scott has spent much of his career trying to avoid letting the color of his skin define his political identity, keeping a line at the ready to offer to new acquaintances: “I am a Christian who is a conservative,” he likes to say, “— and you may have noticed, I’m black.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: How a Once-Loathed Brooklyn Arena Became a Protest Epicenter
description: Barclays Center helped displace hundreds of residents and businesses, but its plaza has become a town square amid the local Black Lives Matter movement.
content: For the first seven-and-a-half years of its existence, the plaza in front of the Barclays Center arena in Brooklyn was primarily a place that people passed through on their way to somewhere else. To the extent that it meant anything to anyone, it was, for some Brooklynites, a symbol of gentrification and displacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: As Baseball Teeters, Rob Manfred’s Words Ring Hollow
description: “It’s just a disaster for our game,” the commissioner said of the lack of trust between M.L.B. and its union. But much of the blame lies with him.
content: Bud Selig presided over a canceled World Series, which would seem to be about as bad as it gets for a baseball commissioner’s legacy. Yet his successor, Rob Manfred, may sink even lower. Manfred just might cancel the entire 2020 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Kurz
title: Want Better Elections? Choose Better Elections Officials
description: Secretaries of state do more than count ballots and issue drivers’ licenses. They safeguard our democracy.
content: The big news from Georgia’s primary election last Tuesday wasn’t who won and who lost. It was the galling meltdown at polling places in black communities across the state. New voting machines were missing or didn’t work. Voters waited hours in line to cast their ballots. Some understandably gave up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Jack Nicas
title: Apple’s App Store Draws Antitrust Scrutiny in European Union
description: After complaints from rivals including Spotify, European authorities will investigate Apple’s App Store.
content: LONDON — Apple’s App Store helped usher in the smartphone economy, leading to the birth of now-ubiquitous services such as Instagram, Uber and Candy Crush, and providing a transformative new way for people to shop from their phones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai, Bill Marsh and Anjali Singhvi
title: Here Are the 98 U.S. Cities Where Protesters Were Tear-Gassed
description: The deployment of tear gas against civilians has not been this widespread since the period of unrest in the 1960s and ’70s, according to a New York Times analysis.
content: The deployment of tear gas against civilians has not been this widespread since the period of unrest in the 1960s and ’70s, according to a New York Times analysis.

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Simon Romero and Lucy Tompkins
title: Reconsidering the Past, One Statue at a Time
description: From Virginia to New Mexico, protests over police brutality have brought hundreds of years of American history bubbling to the surface.
content: The boiling anger that exploded in the days after George Floyd gasped his final breaths is now fueling a national movement to topple perceived symbols of racism and oppression in the United States, as protests over police brutality against African-Americans expand to include demands for a more honest accounting of American history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Honduran President Tests Positive
description: Scientists at the University of Oxford say they have identified a drug that can reduce coronavirus-related deaths. The virus flares in Beijing. Officials in Tulsa, Okla., worry that President Trump’s planned rally could cause a spike.
content: Juan Orlando Hernández, the president of Honduras, announced late Tuesday that he, the first lady and two aides had tested positive for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Retail Sales Rebounded in May, but the Road Back Is Long
description: The recovery is tentative, and it remains to be seen how the pandemic will change consumer behavior and the shopping experience over the long term.
content: Retail sales rebounded sharply in May as thousands of stores and restaurants reopened after lockdowns were lifted and federal stimulus checks and tax refunds fueled a burst of spending, a sign that the United States economy is lurching back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Adam Satariano
title: Europe Rolls Out Contact Tracing Apps, With Hope and Trepidation
description: Italy and Germany activated apps this week as tools to avoid a second wave of coronavirus infections, fueling a debate about privacy rights.
content: ROME — When three people in the northern Italian region of Liguria tested positive for the coronavirus last week, they gave their doctors permission to punch into a national server anonymous codes generated by a new contact tracing app on their phones. Moments later, the phones of people who had also voluntarily downloaded the app and had come into contact with them buzzed with an alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Schools Shut in Beijing as Coronavirus Flares
description: The Chinese capital announced that it would step up its emergency footing in an effort to stamp out an outbreak of infections.
content: Beijing raised its level of health alert to the second highest on Tuesday, ordering schools to close and urging people to work from home as China’s government pressed to extinguish a spike in coronavirus infections menacing the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China outbreak, Brexit, E.U. travel: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Some residential compounds in Beijing were under lockdown on Monday and tens of thousands were tested for the coronavirus as the government rushed to contain a new cluster of infections.

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Coronavirus Accelerates Across Africa
description: The virus was slow to start in many African countries, but epidemiologists say the number of confirmed cases on the continent is now rising fast.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — When Daniel Khan Mbuh died in a hospital in northern Cameroon, the hospital declared the cause of death to be Covid-19 — then released the body to the family instead of arranging for a safe burial, his daughter Stella said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: For 3 Poets Who Embrace Excess, the Mess Is the Message
description: Our poetry columnist reviews “My Baby First Birthday,” by Jenny Zhang, “Toxicon and Arachne,” by Joyelle McSweeney, and “DMZ Colony,” by Don Mee Choi.
content: Because space is limited in our book-crowded apartment, I couldn’t help noticing that a number of the poetry galleys arriving in my mail over the last six to 12 months were taking up as much room on the shelf as novellas or even novels. The spines were an inch thick instead of a centimeter. For example, “A Sand Book,” Ariana Reines’s ninth book, is almost twice as long as our collection of every poem Elizabeth Bishop ever published. (Bishop’s book “Geography III” included just 10 poems.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: In Iraq, a New Prime Minister Takes Stock of His Bloodied Land
description: In one city ruined by war, even the stones seem to have voices. They tell the stories of people who can no longer speak for themselves.
content: MOSUL, Iraq — From the moment Iraq’s new prime minister stepped off the Iraqi Army MI-17 helicopter for a tour of Mosul, the city most damaged by the Islamic State’s takeover in 2014, he plunged into a landscape of loss.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Health care workers in France and Italy, hailed as heroes for their dedication during the coronavirus pandemic, have been demanding improvements such as better pay.

title: Venezuela Court Orders Takeover of 2 Major Opposition Political Parties

title: 4 Charts to Explain the Retail Sales Rise
description: Yes, retail sales took a big jump in May, but they have a lot of ground to make up. Here’s a look at what the numbers mean.
content: Yes, retail sales took a big jump in May, but they have a lot of ground to make up. Here’s a look at what the numbers mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dillon Hayes
title: All I Have to Offer You Is Me
description: Larry Callies comes from a long line of black cowboys living and working on the frontier.
content: Larry Callies comes from a long line of black cowboys living and working on the frontier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: North Korea Blows Up Office Shared With South Korea
description: North Korea on Tuesday blew up a building where its officials and their South Korean counterparts had recently worked side by side.
content: North Korea on Tuesday blew up a building where its officials and their South Korean counterparts had recently worked side by side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz and Katherine Rosman
title: High School Students and Alumni Are Using Social Media to Expose Racism
description: Learning has been online and remote this semester. So too, now, are call-outs of questionable behavior.
content: Over the past few weeks, as the Black Lives Matter movement has grown following outrage over the killing of George Floyd, high school students have leveraged every social media platform to call out their peers for racist behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: When Can Grandparents Meet the Newborn?
description: With precautions in place you may be able to see — and even hold — the newest addition to your family.
content: One of the most difficult aspects of the Covid-19 pandemic is that it is has forced families and friends to miss out on life events. Weddings, birthdays, bat mitzvahs and everything else in between have been canceled or sent to Zoom. Last week, instead of attending a normal graduation ceremony, we drove my oldest around the track of his high school and he was handed a diploma case through a window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: I’m a Critical Care Doctor. I’m Tired, I’m Mourning, I’m Bracing for More.
description: We’re keeping empty units available. The virus is still here.
content: Rushing into the hospital for an overnight shift, I grab my brown paper bag of personal protective equipment, swing open the door to the coronavirus intensive care unit — and stop short. The patients are gone. The halls that were cluttered just a day ago with ventilator monitors are now empty, silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Harry Potter and the Scales of Justice
description: A little bit of good news, in a dire month for L.G.B.T.Q. people.
content: “I used to think people like you should be, you know, exterminated,” the nice young man said to me. “But after listening to you speak, I’ve really changed my mind!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Coronavirus Outbreaks at Border Put Haitian Migrants at Risk
description: Day laborers who lack adequate health care and housing are particularly vulnerable, as cases rise across the Americas.
content: As the coronavirus spreads across Latin America and the Caribbean, public health officials are flagging outbreaks cropping up in several border regions, particularly the one between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: Who’s a Bot? Who’s Not?
description: It sometimes seems that automated bots are taking over social media and driving human discourse. But some (real) researchers aren’t so sure.
content: Over the long Memorial Day weekend, a Twitter storm blew in about bots, those little automatic programs that talk to us in the digital dimension as if they were human.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: C.I.A. Failed to Defend Against Theft of Secrets by Insider, Report Says
description: Better security could have protected hacking tools that were stolen in a large breach and handed over to WikiLeaks, a task force found.
content: WASHINGTON — The 2016 theft of secret C.I.A. hacking tools by an agency officer, one of the largest breaches in agency history, was partly because of failures to install safeguards and officials who ignored the lessons of other government agencies that saw large breaches when employees stole secrets, according to an internal C.I.A. report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Lebron
title: White America Wants Me to Conform. I Won’t Do It.
description: Even at elite universities, I was exposed to the disease that has endangered black lives for so long.
content: It could have been the day I died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: India-China Border, Beijing Outbreak, Restaurants: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak
title: Hungary Moves to End Rule by Decree, but Orban’s Powers May Stay
description: Legislation to drop the state of emergency prompted by the coronavirus was seen by some as effectively codifying Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s extended authority.
content: BUDAPEST — Long before Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary was granted the power to rule by decree to combat the outbreak of the coronavirus, his control over the ruling party and the state itself was pretty much complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: 2 Sidelined Pittsburgh Journalists React: One Quits; the Other Sues
description: Alexis Johnson and Michael Santiago, who are black, said The Post-Gazette had unfairly kept them from covering antiracism protests.
content: The two black journalists at The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette who told The New York Times that their bosses had unfairly kept them from covering protests against racism and police violence have taken steps to redress their complaints.
source.name: The New York Times

title: So You Want to Be a Socially Distanced Orchestra
description: Here is music that could safely be played by a reduced symphonic ensemble.
content: Mahler’s “Symphony of a Thousand” might not be a great idea. Schoenberg’s “Gurrelieder,” with 150 instrumentalists and even more singers? Ditto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Leota Dooley, a Music Lover in the Colorado Mountains, Dies at 97
description: As a member of a singing group, she kept the Salida, Colo., area tuneful. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Powell Warns Pandemic Downturn Could Widen Inequalities
description: Jerome H. Powell, testifying before lawmakers, said recent labor market improvement was encouraging but predicted a long road ahead for service-sector workers.
content: WASHINGTON — Jerome H. Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, told lawmakers on Tuesday that the economy’s nascent rebound was likely to take a long time to reach all corners of the job market — and that already-disadvantaged groups were likely to suffer the most if the downturn drags on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Riding Out Quarantine With a Chatbot Friend: ‘I Feel Very Connected’
description: The digital companions may sound like science fiction. But when social isolation became the norm, they helped deal with the loneliness, some users say.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic reached her neighborhood on the outskirts of Houston, infecting her garbage man and sending everyone else into quarantine, Libby Francola was already reeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Iowa Governor Will Restore Voting Rights to Paroled Felons
description: Gov. Kim Reynolds, a Republican, said she would issue an executive order that would take effect before the November election, ending Iowa’s distinction as the last state to deprive all former felons of voting rights for life.
content: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa said Tuesday that she would issue an executive order to restore voting rights to paroled felons, ending Iowa’s distinction as the last state in the country to strip all former felons of voting rights for life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kaufman
title: How the Pride March Made History
description: Fifty years after the first march, prominent organizers and activists tell its story and talk about how it spread across the globe.
content: This article is part of our latest Pride special report, featuring L.G.B.T.Q. voices on the challenges and possibilities of these troubled times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Surprise! Justice on L.G.B.T. Rights From a Trump Judge
description: So much for “But Gorsuch.”
content: The new season of my favorite television show, “The Good Fight,” begins with the heroine, the feminist lawyer Diane Lockhart, awakening in what seems at first like a giddy alternative reality in which Hillary Clinton won the 2016 election. She remembers the horrors of the last three and a half years, but no one else seems to. A crushing weight lifts as she convinces herself it was all an awful dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: Our Best Fourth of July Recipes
description: Here’s what you need to make the most of the holiday.
content: Independence Day, or the Fourth of July as most of us call it, commemorates the date in 1776 when the Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, a written resolution announcing the United States’ freedom from British rule. (The legal separation actually happened two days before, on July 2.) In our founding fathers’ honor, let’s eat barbecue and set things on fire. Here are our best July 4 recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Mason
title: The Unexpected Beauty of ‘Dog Vomit’ and Other Slime
description: A world of life and color surrounded me during decades of wandering the woods, without my ever having noticed it.
content: They say everybody needs a hobby, and for the past six months, mine has been taking videos and photographs of slime molds in the oak and redwood forests near my home in California. Perhaps we’ve met somewhere on the trail? I was the guy on the ground with a lens clipped to his iPhone, the patient wife, the children asking worriedly from a distance whether a plant was poison oak. Perhaps you may have recognized my “slime-molding outfit”: the frayed Y2K jacket and Old Navy cargo pants caked with mud of many vintages. Perhaps, if you dared ask what I was doing, I popped up and (in those days when strangers stood close to one another) showed you my pictures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Clean Up After Others
description: Wear a face mask, surgical gloves and a uniform or extra-large T-shirt over your clothes that you can peel off.
content: “Protect yourself,” says Vanessa Oltmann, 63, who cleans vacation rentals in Folly Beach, S.C., and during her free time walks along the shore, picking up garbage left by beachgoers. The coronavirus has meant less paid cleaning work and much more detritus on the beach. “It’s just everywhere,” Oltmann says. “I don’t understand it.” If you’re cleaning up after strangers in a pandemic, take precautions: Wear a face mask, surgical gloves and a uniform or extra-large T-shirt over your clothes that you can peel off and put directly in the wash when you’re done. After every job, clean and sanitize your equipment, whether mops and brooms or garbage pickers and five-gallon buckets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner
title: Trump Administration Sues to Try to Delay Publication of Bolton’s Book
description: The request comes a week before the highly anticipated memoir was set to be published.
content: The Trump administration sued the former national security adviser John R. Bolton on Tuesday to try to delay publication of his highly anticipated memoir about his time in the White House, saying the book contained classified information that would compromise national security if it became public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
title: Worst Clash in Decades on Disputed India-China Border Kills 20 Indian Troops
description: Under nationalist leaders, the nuclear-armed rivals have been increasingly assertive toward neighbors, risking open conflict. They have contested their Himalayan border for generations.
content: NEW DELHI — The worst border clash between India and China in more than 40 years left 20 Indian soldiers dead and dozens believed captured, Indian officials said on Tuesday, raising tensions between nuclear-armed rivals who have increasingly been flexing their diplomatic and military muscle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Dismisses Criticism of Law Enforcement (Unless It’s His)
description: President Trump regularly assails law enforcement officials who investigate him or his friends as “dirty cops,” while staunchly defending the police who are accused of mistreating anyone else.
content: One morning last week, President Trump went after the “dirty cops,” as he has called them in the past, complaining that “Police Organizations & National Security Organizations were used to SPY on a Campaign.” Sixty-one minutes later, he was extolling officers as heroes and vowing to stop anyone who wants to defund “our great Police.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: The ‘Poisoned’ Shake Shack Milkshakes and an N.Y.P.D. on Edge
description: Claims that fast-food workers poisoned officers intentionally proved to be unfounded, but the ensuing uproar underscored a tense new dynamic.
content: Around 8:30 p.m. Monday, officials said, three New York City police officers stopped for milkshakes at a Shake Shack restaurant in Lower Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times
